questions.text: A cadaveric specimen of the circle of Willis is given below. Which of the following marked structures represents the superior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric image is of the vascular structures(Circle of Willis) at the base of the brain. The structure marked as 'A' can be identified as the superior cerebellar artery as it arises from the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries(marked as B).

The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum. The branches from this anastomosis supply diffrent parts of the brain.

The posterior communicating artery forms the link between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems by connecting the posterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the basilar artery) with the internal carotid arteries. The anterior communicating artery connects the anterior cerebral arteries of the two sides (branches of the internal carotid artery).

 

 

 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A patient with salicylic acid poisoning has the following arterial blood gas analysis report : pH = 7.1, pCO2 =18mmHg, HCO3-=12mmol/L. The acid-base disorder here is_____

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder here is a mixed disorder of metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

It should not be confused with metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. This can be understood by the following calculation:

Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.1 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis

Step 2: HCO3- is 12 mmol/L (Normal HCO3- - 22–30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO3- levels decrease.

Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: As per Winter's formula, the expected respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis can be calculated using,

      pCO2 =( 1.5 x [HCO3-] ) +8 ± 2

In this case, Expected pCO2 = ( 1.5 x [12] ) +8 ± 2

                                          = 26 ± 2

                                          = 24 - 28 mmHg

The pCO2 in this patient is 18 mmHg, which implies there is an overcompensation of pCO2. This overcompensation can happen only if there is an additional component of respiratory alkalosis contributing to reduced pCO2.

Hence, this patient has a mixed disorder - metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 34-year-old male whose staple diet primarily consisted of only maize presents with diarrhea, dementia, and photosensitive dermatitis in sun-exposed areas. Which vitamin is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Maize contains niacin in bound form and is unavailable for absorption. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

Casal’s necklace pattern classically seen in pellagra is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar.

Pellagra occurs despite an adequate intake of tryptophan & niacin in the case of

  • Carcinoid syndrome as tryptophan will be used up in the production of serotonin 
  • Hartnup disease due to a defect in the tryptophan transporter resulting in intestinal malabsorption and failure of renal reabsorption.

Niacin significantly decreases concentrations of all apoB-containing lipoproteins like VLDL, IDL, LDL, and lipoprotein a. It also increases HDL cholesterol.

Niacin toxicity occurs when it is taken in excess quantity for the treatment of hyperlipidemia and manifests as

  • Prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Fulminant hepatitis (the most serious complication)
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Macular edema and macular cysts 

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

questions.text: Identify the pathological red blood cell form shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The pathological red blood cell form seen in the peripheral smear is an acanthocyte.

Acanthocytes are red blood cells with spicules of various sizes at regular intervals on the cell surface.

Conditions with acanthocytes include-

  • Renal disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy/ hyposplenism.

Other options- 

Option A: Dacrocytes or tear-drop cells are seen in myelofibrosis, myelodysplastic syndromes, hemolytic anemias, and thalassemias.  

 

 Option C: Echinocyte or Burr cells are characterized by projections of the red cell membrane that are smaller, regularly spaced, smoothly rounded crenulations, and much more uniform in shape and distribution in contrast to the acanthocytes. They are seen in anemia of renal disease (uremia), in premature infants, after exchange transfusion, and may sometimes be seen as storage artifacts.

 

Option D: Schistocytes or helmet cells are fragmented RBCs that are seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias and mechanical valves.

questions.text: The serological profile of a patient is as follows: HBsAg: + ve; HBeAg: + ve; Anti HBc: IgM: + ve;  Anti HBs: - ve; Anti HBe: - ve. What is your diagnosis?

choices.text: Acute HBV infection with high infectivity
Acute HBV infection with low infectivity

questions.solution:
HBsAg and IgM Anti-HBc is positive, indicating an acute hepatitis B infection. HBeAg positive indicates that the patient is highly infectious.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

  HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc
Acute HBV, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM

Acute HBV-Window period

-

 - +/- +/- IgM
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG
Recovery - + - +/- IgG

Immunization with HBsAg

 - + - - -

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication for the use of corticosteroids in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?

choices.text: Management of acute disease flares while on therapy with DMARDs
As bridging therapy initially, till DMARDs take effect
Chronic therapy in cases that cannot be controlled with DMARDs
As monotherapy for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis

questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids are not used as monotherapy for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

They may be administered as bridging therapy initially to achieve rapid disease control till Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drugs (DMARDs) take effect. DMARDs take several weeks or even months to show full effect. (Option B)

A burst of glucocorticoids for 1-2 weeks may be prescribed to manage acute disease flares. (Option A)

Chronic therapy with low doses may be needed to control the disease in patients with an inadequate response to DMARD therapy. (Option C)

High doses of glucocorticoids may be needed to treat severe extraarticular manifestations of RA.

Intraarticular injection of triamcinolone can be considered for one/few actively inflamed joints.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections deals with McNaughton's rule?
questions.solution:
IPC section 84 deals with McNaughten’s rule.

McNaughten’s rule:

  • It was formed by the Judges of McNaughten’s case, to clarify the common law of insanity in England during 1843. It is similar to IPC 84 that states “Nothing is offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it by reason of unsoundness of mind is incapable of knowing the nature of act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law”.
  • This form the basis of the ‘test’ of insanity that the jury should be instructed to apply in each case of alleged insanity.
  • The rules are:
    • Every man is presumed to be sane and to possess a sufficient degree of reason to be responsible for his crimes, until the contrary be proved to their satisfaction.
    • To establish an insanity defence, it must be clearly proved that, at the time of the committing of the act, the accused was laboring under ‘such a defect of reason, from a disease of the mind, as not to know the nature and quality of the act he was doing; or if he did know it, that he did not know he was doing what was wrong’.

McNaughten’s rule now comes under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS Section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

18

-

A person is not liable for an accident in doing a lawful act

20

82

Child under 7 years is not liable for act.

21

83

Child of 7–12 years if not attained proper mental maturity is not liable for act.

22

84  -McNaughten's rule

A person of unsound mind is not liable for act.

23

85

A person who under involuntary intoxication has commited an act is not liable for the act.

24

86

A person who under voluntary intoxication commits an act is liable for the act.

Related Pearl: IPC Sec 84, McNaughten's rule

McNaughten's rule, Section 84 IPC:  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

It states that an accused is not criminally responsible if he was suffering from:

  • Defect of reason and unsoundness of mind: the law recognizes only those diseases which impair the thinking abilities of the mind. So, not all medically insane people are legally insane, as emotional disturbances that affect the mind are not considered if they do not directly affect cognition.
  • That he did not know the nature and the quality of the act he is doing:  the law needs the unsoundness of mind to exist at the time of the act to such a degree that the person is not aware of what he is doing and whether it is right or wrong to do. Absence of a motive or forethought is also considered as a criteria for determining unsoundness of mind.

McNaughten’s rule now comes under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

questions.text: A patient with middle ear fluid accumulation is tested using tympanometry. What is the expected tympanogram finding seen in this case?

choices.text: Compliance is high at or near ambient air pressure
Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure
Maximum compliance occurs with negative pressure

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of middle ear fluid accumulation, the expected tympanogram finding would be a flat or dome-shaped graph.

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube.

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.

Tympanometry is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

By charting the compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs called tympanograms are obtained. They are as follows:

The image given below shows impedance audiometry. Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels.

  • To deliver a tone of 220Hz
  • To absorb reflected sound
  • To change the pressure in the external auditory canal

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which of the following is the best investigation for foreign body localization?
questions.solution:
CT scan is the best method for intraocular foreign body (IOFB) localization.

The foreign bodies most likely to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel. While chipping stone with an iron chisel, the chip of the iron chisel is more likely to enter the eye than the stone. A foreign body entering the eye may cause damage by:

  • mechanical effects
  • introduction of infection
  • reacting with the intraocular tissues

Anteroposterior and lateral view X-rays are recommended for locating an IOFB as most foreign bodies are radio-opaque. Ultrasonographic localization can tell the position of even non-radiopaque foreign bodies. CT scan is the best method of IOFB localization.

MRI is contraindicated for metallic IOFB.MRI can be detrimental for a patient with a history of an intraocular foreign body (IOFB) after cutting stone with a hammer and chisel. It can cause further damage by producing movements of the foreign body if it is magnetic. The use of MRI is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies and is not recommended as a screening procedure.

Management: A foreign body should always be removed unless:

  • it is inert and probably sterile
  • little damage has been done to vision 
  • the process of removal will destroy sight

 

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and cause atrophy.

Clinical features:

  • Iris: first stained greenish and later turns reddish-brown, causing heterochromia iridis.
  • Pupil: iron deposition in sphincter leads to mydriasis.
  • Lens: iron deposition in a radial fashion on the anterior capsule of the lens, leading to anterior capsular cataract.
  • Retina: pigmentary retinopathy; followed by atrophy of the retina and retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • Secondary open-angle Glaucoma: due to damage to the trabecular meshwork.

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient with increased blood pressure has come to the outpatient department. He asks about lifestyle modifications and a DASH diet was suggested. How much does the systolic blood pressure drop by adopting the DASH diet?

DASH: Dietary approaches to stop hypertension
questions.solution:
The systolic blood pressure drops by 8-14 mmHg by adopting the DASH diet.

DASH is a diet plan which involves consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced saturated and total fat content. 

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension and the reduction in blood pressure are shown below.

Modification Impact on SBP
Weight reduction to maintain a normal body mass index  5–20 mmHg per 10  kg weight loss
DASH diet  8–14 mmHg

Sodium intake reduction 
(< 6 grams of sodium chloride)

  2–8 mmHg
Physical activity: 30 minutes of a brisk walk per day  4–9 mmHg
Limit alcohol consumption
(≤2 drinks/day)		  2-4 mmHg

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease. The rule of halves states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

Hypertension is a preventable disease. There are two approaches:

  • Primary prevention - it includes measures that are taken to reduce the incidence by reducing the risk of onset. Population strategies are dietary modification, weight reduction, and exercise. A high-risk strategy prevents the shooting of blood pressure which might need institutional treatment. 
  • Secondary prevention - it includes the detection and usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals.  

Related Pearl: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

Indication

Initial treatment of choice 

Hypertension alone or hypertension with diabetes/ cerebrovascular disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with coronary artery disease

ACEi/ ARB + beta blocker/CCB (A+B or A+C)

or

beta-blocker + diuretic (B+D)

or 

CCB+ diuretic/ beta-blocker (C+B or C+D)

Hypertension with chronic kidney disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction

ACEI/ ARB + diuretic + beta-blocker (A+D+B)

Pregnancy

Labetalol, Nifedipine, methyldopa

ACEi – Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

ARB – Angiotensin II receptor blockers

CCB – Calcium Channel Blockers

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of RCH program?
questions.solution:
The Reproductive and child health program(RCH) does not include women's education and empowerment as a component.

RCH program deals with the health status of young women and young children. The main objectives are reducing the total fertility rate, infant mortality rate and maternal mortality rate. It involves the following components:

  • Essential and emergency obstetric care
  • Control of reproductive tract infections (RTI) and sexually transmitted diseases (STD)
  • Safe abortion services
  • Full range of family planning services including laparoscopic services
  • Essential newborn care and immunization
  • Emergency care of sick children including diarrhoeal and acute respiratory disease
  • Prevention and control of vitamin A deficiency and anaemia in children.

questions.text: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the program whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except:

choices.text: Two rounds of spraying with DDT should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) should be provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index ≥ 5.
Indoor Residual Sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.
In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.

questions.solution:
Under the Integrated vector management initiative, Indoor Residual Sprays are the main methods of vector control in rural areas. 

National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya. 

Integrated Vector Management:

  • For adult mosquitoes:
    • Indoor residual Sprays are used. It is the main method of vector control in rural areas.
    • DDT is the insecticide of choice.
    • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT and in DDT-resistant areas, three rounds of spraying are done with Malathion (if DDT-resistant).
  • For the larvae: Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.
  • For personal protection: 
    • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥ 2.
    • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API ≥ 5.

The Drug distribution centers only dispense anti-malarial drugs under the NVBDCP for Malaria. 

Important points about the organization for the anti-Malaria program:

  • Central Government: Supplies DDT and larvicides.
  • State government: Procures the Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) for the districts.
  • District Malaria Office: Key unit for the implementation of the program.
  • District Malaria Officer: Has direct responsibility for IRS spraying operations and is assisted by one Assistant Malaria Officer and Malaria Inspectors. 
  • Medical officer of the PHC:  Has the overall responsibility for the surveillance and laboratory services.
  • Multi-Purpose Workers and ASHAs: Carry out surveillance and case detection in the community.
  • Drug Distribution Centres: Only dispensing anti-malarial drugs.
  • Fever Treatment Depots: Dispense the anti-malarial drugs and collect the blood slides.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of RTA (renal tubular acidosis ) type II  except
questions.solution:
Medullary sponge kidney causes RTA Type I 

Causes of RTA type II

  • Amyloidosis
  • Wilson's disease
  • Galactosemia
  • Hereditary fructose intolerance
  • Cystinosis

Causes of RTA Type I

  • Autoimmune diseases like SLE, Sjogren Syndrome
  • Drugs: amphotericin, lithium, aminoglycosides
  • Medullary sponge kidney

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with the finding shown in the given image. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.

Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.

Clubbing can occur secondary to:

  • Pulmonary disease: Lung cancer, bronchiectasis, asbestosis, sarcoidosis, lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, tuberculosis, and mesothelioma
  • Cardiac disease: Cyanotic congenital heart disease, other causes of right-to-left shunting, and bacterial endocarditis.
  • Gastrointestinal disease: Ulcerative colitis, Crohn disease, primary biliary cirrhosis, cirrhosis of the liver.
  • Skin disease: Palmoplantar keratoderma, and Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
  • Malignancies: Thyroid cancer, thymus cancer, Hodgkin disease, and disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes with complaints of tremor in his right hand. The tremor is most apparent at rest and improves with movement. He also says that he has difficulty initiating movements and his wife says his movements have been slow. On examination, rigidity is observed to passive arm movement and shuffling gait with a stooped posture is noticed.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathology of this condition?

choices.text: Substantia nigra pars reticulata is unaffected by the disease process
Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta
Lewy bodies which contain degenerated tau protein are seen

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease and Lewy bodies seen in Parkinson's disease do not contain tau protein. They contain the protein α-synuclein.

Pathologic hallmarks of Parkinson's disease :

  • Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc)
  • Reduced striatal dopamine
  • Intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions called Lewy bodies, which contain the protein α-synuclein

questions.text: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. On examination, there is tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes, and abdominal ultrasound is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the ultrasound image showing multiple septations and rosette or honeycomb appearance is diagnostic of active hydatid cyst.

Hydatid cyst:

Echinococcus granulosus is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts, while Echinococcus multilocularis and Echinococcus ligartus account for a small number of cases.

The hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called the pericyst that is derived from the host tissue.

The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.

The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts.

The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

The image attached below shows the C.S of hydatid cyst.

 

Investigations: 

Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa.

CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and higher sensitivity to demonstrate the daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. 
The indirect hemagglutination test and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have a sensitivity of 80% overall and are the initial screening tests of choice.

Note:

  • First/Initial imaging test: USG
  • Best imaging test: CT scan

Classification of CE based on ultrasound imaging

Type Ultrasound features Stage
CE1 Univesicular fluid collection Active Cyst
CE2 Honeycomb appearance: Multivesicular fluid collection with daughter cysts separated by septae
CE3A Water lily sign: Fluid collection with detached membrane Transitional cyst
CE3B Daughter cysts present in a solid matrix
CE4 Cysts in a heterogeneous matrix with no daughter cysts Inactive/dead cyst
CE5 Solid cystic wall

 Management:

Class Management
CE1 

<5 cm albendazole 400 mg PO BID

 >5 cm albendazole 400 mg PO BID+ PAIR
CE3a

<5 cm albendazole 400 mg PO BID

>5 cm albendazole  PO BID+ PAIR
CE2, CE3b

PAIR contraindicated

Large bore percutaneous treatment

Surgery+albendazole 400 mg PO BID.
CE4 & 5

PAIR contraindicated

Observation (ultrasonography preferred every 6 months)

 

 CE: cystic echinococcosis

PO: per oral

BID: twice daily

PAIR: puncture, aspiration, injection, and reaspiration

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a.

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: Given below instrument is used:
questions.solution:
Image shows kehr’s T tube with vertical and horizontal limb.
It is used after exploration of CBD i.e. horizontal limb is placed in CBD and vertical limb is brought out as drain.

It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.
Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimise the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal.
However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones, some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.

questions.text: 10 months old male baby presented with an empty scrotum. Ultrasonography revealed that the right testis was found in the right inguinal canal, while the left testis was found in the perineum.  Comment on the diagnosis of this baby.

choices.text: Right side undescended testis and left sided ectopic testis
Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis

questions.solution:
Since the right testis is found in the inguinal canal which is along the normal path of descent it is called an undescended testis, while the left testis lies in the perineum which is an ectopic site of descent and is called an ectopic testis.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated byandrogen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

 

Ectopic testis is can be present anywhere along the normal path of descent from the abdomen to the scrotum. Other ectopic sites outside the normal path includes: 

  • Femoral triangle
  • The root of the penis
  • Perineum.

An ectopic testis is usually treated with orchidopexy.

 

The image below shows the possible ectopic sites of the testes:

A retractile testis is a normally developed and descended testis that retracts back into the inguinal canal due to hyper reflexive cremasteric muscle contraction.

Therefore any stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. When the cremaster relaxes, the testis reappears in the scrotum.

The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal (normal rugosity is seen).

Retractile testes require no treatment 

Note: Chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis because both of them describe a condition, wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position. 

Chair Test:  Here, The young patient is asked to sit on a chair hugging his knees to his chest. This maneuver helps the retractile testis to get pushed down back to the bottom of the scrotum. By this test retractile testis can be differentiated from the ectopic testis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of phyllodes tumour or cystosarcoma phyllodes of the breast.

Phyllodes tumour is also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes presents as a large tumour with an unevenly bosselated surface. The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture.

Phyllodes tumours usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. It is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some having low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

This tumour does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare. Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant type- Mastectomy

Other options:

Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign, solid, encapsulated, and biphasic tumour consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined glands. It is a slow-growing tumour and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases. Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a rapid onset of disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: Given instrument is:
questions.solution:
Minnesota tube has 4 openings – 2 suction tubes and 2 inflation tubes.

  • Suction tubes allows aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

Remember : 

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumen.

It has ports for gastric and esophageal balloons and a gastric aspiration port.

The Minnesota tube or modified-Sengstaken Blakemore tube has 4 lumen with an additional oesophageal aspiration port.

questions.text: A primi gravida mother in a 1st degree consanguineous marriage undergoes a quadruple screening test during the second trimester. The test results indicate a chromosomal anomaly of Trisomy 21.  Which of the following changes can be seen in the quadruple screening test?

choices.text: Lower  β-hCG, Inhibin and elevated estriol, AFP
Elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP
Elevated β-hCG, PAPP-A and lower estriol, AFP
Lower β-hCG, PAPP-A and elevated estriol, AFP

questions.solution:
Quadruple screening is a second trimester multiple marker screening test for the detection of chromosomal anomalies like trisomy 21-Down syndrome.  

Pregnancies with Down syndrome are characterized by elevated β-hCG, Inhibin and lower estriol, AFP levels.  It is performed from 15 to 21 weeks of gestation. 

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes,

  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A),
  • With the sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT).

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks’ gestation.

In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower.

With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

The abnormalities seen on quadruple screen are tabulated below:

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Low Normal

questions.text: The following image depicts _______
questions.solution:
The above image depicts frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Footling Knee presentation Complete/flexed
Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Both thighs and legs are partially extended Thighs extended, Knee flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed.
Presenting part: Buttocks and genitalia Foot Knee Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation?
questions.solution:
The label marked 2 represents the LH surge ,which is responsible for ovulation.

Phases of the menstrual cycle:

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are upregulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause the proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • It occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Progesterone levels are high.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for the receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

A schematic diagram of the menstrual cycle and the changes occurring is shown below:

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: A baby assessed five minutes after birth is found to be blue with irregular gasping respiration. The heart rate is 50 beats/min, and a grimace is seen in response to stimulation with a catheter in the nostrils. On assessing the baby's muscle tone, you note that there is some flexion of the extremities. The APGAR score for this newborn is
questions.solution:
The APGAR score of this newborn is 4.

In this baby:

  • Colour blue - score 0
  • HR < 60/min - score 1
  • Grimace - score 1
  • Some flexion of extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

Thus total score in this patient is 4

SIGN   0 1 2
Colour (A – appearance) Blue, pale Body pink, extremities blue Completely pink 
Heart rate (P – pulse) Absent Below 100 Over 100
Response to a catheter in nostril (G – grimace)(tested after oropharynx is clear) No response Grimace Cough or sneeze 
Muscle tone (A - activity) Limp Some flexion of extremities Active motion 
Respiratory effort (R)   Absent  Slow, irregular Good, crying
  • At 1 minute and 5 minutes after complete birth of the infant (disregarding the cord and placenta), the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated, and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.
  • A total score of 10 indicates an infant in the best possible condition.
  • An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed a medial collateral ligament injury. Which other structure is most commonly associated with this type of injury?
questions.solution:
The medial collateral ligament injury is commonly associated with medial meniscus injury as they are components of the unhappy triad of O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle.

The medial meniscus is less mobile than the lateral, and it cannot as easily accommodate to abnormal stresses. This is why meniscal lesions are more common on the medial side than on the lateral.

The unhappy triad of O’Donoghue consists of injury to

  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Medial collateral ligament
  • Medial meniscus

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called as – O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triangle. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to lateral blow to the knee. It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

Image: Unhappy triad injury in MRI (after O'Donoghue) of the knee joint (PDW SPIR). Left to right: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament, rupture of the medial collateral ligament, and inner meniscal tear (here complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: The following are features of antisocial personality disorder except:

choices.text: Failure to conform to social norms
The individual is at least 15 years old

questions.solution:
The individual should be at least 18 years old for diagnosing antisocial personality disorder.

DSM - 5 diagnostic criteria for antisocial personality disorder:

  • Three or more of the following, occurring since age 15 years :
    • Failure to conform to social norms.
    • Deceitfulness, like repeated lying.
    • lmpulsivity or failure to plan ahead.
    • Irritability and aggressiveness.
    • Reckless disregard for safety of self or others.
    • Consistent irresponsibility.
    • Lack of remorse.
  • The individual is at least age 18 years.
  • There is evidence of conduct disorder with onset before age 15 years.
  • The occurrence of antisocial behavior is not exclusively during schizophrenia or bipolar disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following is most suitable for intravenous regional anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Lidocaine is the most preferred drug for intravenous regional anesthesia.

Intravenous Regional Anesthesia or Bier’s block:

  • Intravenous administration of LA into a tourniquet-occluded limb.
  • Anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<45-60 minutes) on the limbs(such as the excision of soft tissue masses or carpal tunnel release)
  • LA commonly used are Lidocaine (most common), followed by Prilocaine, Mepivacaine, Chloroprocaine, Procaine, and Etidocaine.
  • For upper limbs, 40 mL of 0.5% lidocaine without epinephrine is used.
  • For lower limbs, 50 to 100 mL of 0.25% lidocaine without epinephrine is used.

Complications following Bier's block are postoperative pain, difficulty in providing bloodless field, and in rare cases may lead to compartment syndrome due to increased pressure applied. Premature deflation of the tourniquet or increased dose of local anesthesia may lead to systemic toxicity.

Bupivacaine (Option A) is no longer used for Biers block. This is because Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic (LA). Accidental early deflation of the tourniquet can lead to massive systemic doses of bupivacaine resulting in cardiac arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse.

The image below shows Bier's block/ IVRA. 

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine

Naturally occurring

Vasoconstrictor

1st Local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine

Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine

Safest

Causes maximum methemoglobinemia

Suitable for Bier’s IV block

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

Long acting

Most cardiotoxic

Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia

Toxicity  is treated with amiodarone, bretyllium(for VT), vasopressors e.g. epinephrine, vasopressin (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia

1st synthetic LA

Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A patient presents with joint pain which increases in the early morning when he wakes up and decreases with activity. Examination reveals the following picture (given below) along with inflammation of the wrist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the above image with nail pitting and yellowing of the nails and inflammation of the DIP joints, point to a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disease with joint and nail manifestations apart from the skin. It has silvery scales.

The joint manifestations in psoriasis are referred to as psoriatic arthritis. It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy and hence it is associated with HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement.

Other features:

  • Psoriatic nail changes like yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Inflammation of the toes- dactylitis
  • Shortening of toes- telescoping (because of osteolysis)
  • Severe deformity- suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Associated heel pain- suggestive of enthesitis (pain at the sites of ligament/tendon attachment)

The x-ray shows 'pencil in cup' deformity due to tapering of phalanges with cupping of proximal parts. Also all the bones of a single digit maybe involved refered to as ray deformity.

The drug of choice for different types of psoriasis is shown in the pearl below.

The most likely diagnosis for this patient's joint pain, which worsens in the early morning and improves with activity, along with the given picture showing nail changes and inflammation of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, is Psoriatic Arthritis.

Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It is categorized under the seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is often linked to the presence of HLA-B27. It is seen in 5-30% of patients with cutaneous manifestations. Nail involvement increases the risk of concomitant joint involvement. 

Some key features associated with psoriatic arthritis:

  • Psoriatic nail changes like yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Inflammation of the toes - dactylitis (sausage appearance).
  • Shortening of toes - telescoping (because of osteolysis)
  • Severe deformity - suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Associated heel pain - suggestive of enthesitis (pain at the sites of ligament/tendon attachment)
  • Radiographic findings, including the "pencil-in-cup" deformity, which results from the tapering of phalanges and cupping of proximal parts.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text: A newborn is seen to have an abnormal lump in the lower back. Identify the condition from the MRI given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI demonstrates meningocele.

Meningocele is formed when meninges herniate through a defect in the posterior vertebral arches. Patients present with a fluctuant midline mass that is covered with skin. Transillumination through the swelling may be present.

Other options:

Option B: Myelomeningocele is a severe form of incomplete fusion of the vertebral column. Meninges and spinal cord herniate through the gap. Patients commonly present with a lumbosacral defect covered by a thin layer of epithelialized tissue. It is associated with flaccid paralysis of lower limbs.

Option C: Spina bifida occulta is a midline defect of the vertebral bodies without protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges.

Option D: Lissencephaly is a disorder characterized by a lack of cerebral convolutions.

questions.text:
The device shown in the image given below is used in.

HDR - High dose rate
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a remote afterloader. Remote afterloading is related to brachytherapy.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

The following isotopes are used in brachytherapy:

  • I-125 and Iridium-192 - used in low dose rate (LDR) brachytherapy. 
  • Cobalt-60 - is used for high dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

Afterloading is the process of placing the radioactive material into the target region. This is either done manually by the oncologist, or by using remote afterloading devices.

Remote afterloading devices enable us to eliminate direct contact with radioactive sources while administration. It provides protection from radiation exposure to healthcare professionals by securing the radiation source in a shielded safe manner.
